# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 212, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 368, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 213, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 821, 96]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(2x^{3} + x^{2} - px - 5 = 0\) , where \(p\) is a positive constant, has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 526, 126]]<|/det|>
State, in terms of \(p\), the value of \(\alpha \beta + \beta \gamma + \gamma \alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 292, 146, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 292, 472, 311]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^2 \beta \gamma + \alpha \beta^2 \gamma + \alpha \beta \gamma^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 292, 920, 311]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 576, 92]]<|/det|>
Deduce a cubic equation whose roots are \(\alpha \beta , \beta \gamma , \alpha \gamma\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 320, 143, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 536, 339]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\alpha^{2} + \beta^{2} + \gamma^{2} = \frac{1}{3}\), find the value of \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 320, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 677, 91]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the list of formulae (MF19) to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 100, 698, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{N}r(r + 1)(3r + 4) = \frac{1}{12} N(N + 1)(N + 2)(9N + 19). \quad [3]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 809, 104]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{3r + 4}{r(r + 1)}\) in partial fractions and hence use the method of differences to find

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 106, 576, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{N}\frac{3r + 4}{r(r + 1)}\Big(\frac{1}{4}\Big)^{r + 1}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 168, 267, 186]]<|/det|>
in terms of \(N\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 828, 186, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 816, 479, 864]]<|/det|>
Deduce the value of \(\sum_{r = 1}^{\infty} \frac{3r + 4}{r(r + 1)} \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{r + 1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 829, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 92, 94, 111]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 547, 121]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \left( \begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{2} & -\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{3} \\ \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{3} & \frac{1}{2} \end{array} \right) \left( \begin{array}{cc} 14 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array} \right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 136, 146, 155]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 848, 156]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 920, 188]]<|/det|>
Give full details of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 186, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 656, 526]]<|/det|>
Write \(\mathbf{M}^{-1}\) as the product of two matrices, neither of which is \(\mathbf{I}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 507, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 885, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\). [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 710, 732, 730]]<|/det|>
The triangle \(ABC\) in the \(x-y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto triangle \(DEF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 737, 752, 757]]<|/det|>
Given that the area of triangle \(DEF\) is \(28 \mathrm{cm}^2\), find the area of triangle \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 737, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 435, 89]]<|/det|>
The points \(A, B, C\) have position vectors

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 102, 720, 122]]<|/det|>
\[2\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} + 4\mathbf{k},\qquad 2\mathbf{i} + 4\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k},\qquad -3\mathbf{i} - 3\mathbf{j} + 4\mathbf{k},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 405, 152]]<|/det|>
respectively, relative to the origin \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 821, 183]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the plane \(ABC\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 457, 91]]<|/det|>
The point \(D\) has position vector \(\mathbf{2i} + \mathbf{j} + 3\mathbf{k}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 608, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the perpendicular distance from \(D\) to the plane \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 144, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 593, 307]]<|/det|>
Find the shortest distance between the lines \(AB\) and \(CD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 288, 920, 307]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 562, 104]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{x^{2} + ax + 1}{x + 2}\), where \(a > \frac{5}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 487, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 395, 186, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 395, 448, 413]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) has no stationary points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 394, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 685, 94]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^2 = (\pi - \theta)\tan^{-1}(\pi - \theta)\), for \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 781, 126]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state the polar coordinates of the point of \(C\) furthest from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 323, 144, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 323, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
Using the substitution \(u = \pi - \theta\), or otherwise, find the area of the region enclosed by \(C\) and the initial line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 338, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 599, 89]]<|/det|>
Show that, at the point of \(C\) furthest from the initial line,

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 101, 734, 133]]<|/det|>
\[2(\pi -\theta)\tan^{-1}(\pi -\theta)\cot \theta -\frac{\pi -\theta}{1 + (\pi -\theta)^2} -\tan^{-1}(\pi -\theta) = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 152, 665, 171]]<|/det|>
and verify that this equation has a root for \(\theta\) between 1.2 and 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 153, 920, 171]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 826, 920, 865]]<|/det|>
